snippet: The decision came as the risk of Syrian Army missile attacks seemed to have eased and as concerns about Iran and North Korea demanded that the antimissile systems be made available for other missions.
abstract: American officials intend to remove missile defense systems placed in Turkey in 2013; moves suggests threat of missile attacks from Syrian Army has passed and antimissile batteries are needed to defend against threats elsewhere.

byline.contributor: Michael R. Gordon contributed reporting from Washington, and Ceylan Yeginsu from Bodrum, Turkey.

lead_paragraph: The decision came as the risk of Syrian Army missile attacks seemed to have eased and as concerns about Iran and North Korea demanded that the antimissile systems be made available for other missions.

headline.main: After Delicate Negotiations, U.S. Says It Will Pull Patriot Missiles From Turkey
headline.print_headline: After Delicate Negotiations, U.S. Says It Will Pull Patriot Missiles From Turkey

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
